column4: whenever I update the kernel, the new kernel is added on top of the list in grub .... is it possible to clean the grub menu list automatically, so that you only have one working kernel and not a list of 6 different kernels?
apt-get autoremove should remove the no longer needed kernels
but it attempts to remove a lot of different packages
yes, it removes the packages no longer needed, that was automatically installed because of something else
it is removing wine! orgh!
well then I guess you have to remove the kernel packages manually instead
oh £$^£$$&%!!!!! It has removed wine and the configuration .....
are you sure it removed the configuration? try installing wine again, default is not to purge the config
that's what I thought anyway.
who on earth is configuring the autoremove to remove packages that are linked to existing packages?????
I have no idea, mine doesn't do that.
apt-get is from the repository, it is not the kind of package you want to go and modify ....
and it did not clean up the kernels ....
then you have to find the kernel packages and remove them with dpkg. I usually do dpkg --list | grep <kernel version> and then cut/paste the ones I want to remove into dpkg --remove
yes, you can do it manually, but I would have thought tjere was a automatic way of doing it. Thanks a lot for your help.
well, it's automatic on my system, I just removed the -14 kernel using autoremove
did you install from scratch or updated automatically?
this is an 8.10 installation updated to 9.04 and then to 9.10
but I removed the 9.04 kernels manually.
32 bit? 64 bit?
32bit.
